articles.headline: Job Woes Exacting a Toll on Family Life
articles.snippet: The recession’s damage often extends to children, who absorb more than their parents are fully aware of.
articles.abstract: The recession’s damage often extends to children, who absorb more than their parents are fully aware of.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE WOODLANDS, Tex.  Paul Bachmuth’s 9-year-old daughter, Rebecca, began pulling out strands of her hair over the summer. His older child, Hannah, 12, has become noticeably angrier, more prone to throwing tantrums.

articles.headline: Hewlett-Packard to Acquire 3Com
articles.snippet: The $2.7 billion deal, valued at $7.90 a share, has already been approved by directors of both companies.
articles.abstract: The $2.7 billion deal, valued at $7.90 a share, has already been approved by directors of both companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard said on Wednesday that it had reached an agreement to acquire 3Com, a provider of computer network equipment, for $2.7 billion in a deal that H.P. plans as a springboard for an assault on the market leader in networking, Cisco Systems.

articles.headline: Big Sensors, Shrinking Cameras
articles.snippet: Canon and Panasonic introduce two cameras that take giant technological steps.
articles.abstract: Canon and Panasonic introduce two cameras that take giant technological steps.
articles.lead_paragraph: Why can’t someone just build the perfect camera? I mean, come on  we’re not asking for the world, just a handful of prerequisites:

articles.headline: U.S. Envoy Urges Caution on Forces for Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The U.S. ambassador to Afghanistan, Karl W. Eikenberry, expressed reservations about deploying additional troops, senior officials said.
articles.abstract: The U.S. ambassador to Afghanistan, Karl W. Eikenberry, expressed reservations about deploying additional troops, senior officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The United States ambassador to Afghanistan, who once served as the top American military commander there, has expressed in writing his reservations about deploying additional troops to the country, three senior American officials said Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Elisabeth Bumiller and Mark Landler

articles.headline: Among Late-Night Writers, Few Women in the Room
articles.snippet: Very few women make it inside the writing rooms for late-night television hosts, despite the fact that women make up a larger proportion of their audience than men.
articles.abstract: Very few women make it inside the writing rooms for late-night television hosts, despite the fact that women make up a larger proportion of their audience than men.
articles.lead_paragraph: In many ways, television today is about women more than men.

articles.headline: As Shipping Slows, Banks and Carriers Fear Loan Defaults
articles.snippet: As ship owners confront plummeting charter rates from a 25 percent drop in global trade, fears have increased about the recovery of European banks with large shipping industry portfolios.
articles.abstract: As ship owners confront plummeting charter rates from a 25 percent drop in global trade, fears have increased about the recovery of European banks with large shipping industry portfolios.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  When Eastwind Maritime, a medium-size carrier company, went bankrupt this summer, few banks in the United States took notice.

articles.headline: In Leaning on Karzai, U.S. Has Limited Leverage
articles.snippet: At the center of President Obama’s Afghanistan strategy review is the question of how much leverage the U.S. has over President Hamid Karzai.
articles.abstract: At the center of President Obama’s Afghanistan strategy review is the question of how much leverage the U.S. has over President Hamid Karzai.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When President Obama delivered a rare and public call last week for President Hamid Karzai to crack down on corruption in Afghanistan, there was one glaring omission from his remarks  an “or else.”

articles.headline: Lou Dobbs Abruptly Quits CNN
articles.snippet: Lou Dobbs, the CNN anchor whose views on immigration made him a lightning rod, is leaving the network.
articles.abstract: Lou Dobbs, the CNN anchor whose views on immigration made him a lightning rod, is leaving the network.
articles.lead_paragraph: Months ago the president of CNN/U.S., Jonathan Klein, offered a choice to Lou Dobbs, the channel’s most outspoken anchor. Mr. Dobbs could vent his opinions on radio and anchor an objective newscast on television, or he could leave CNN.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Bill Carter

articles.headline: U.S. Adviser to Kurds Stands to Reap Oil Profits
articles.snippet: Peter W. Galbraith, a former U.S. ambassador, could earn millions as a result of his ties to the Iraqi Kurds and a Norwegian oil company.
articles.abstract: Peter W. Galbraith, a former U.S. ambassador, could earn millions as a result of his ties to the Iraqi Kurds and a Norwegian oil company.
articles.lead_paragraph: OSLO  Peter W. Galbraith, an influential former American ambassador, is a powerful voice on Iraq who helped shape the views of policy makers like Joseph R. Biden Jr. and John Kerry. In the summer of 2005, he was also an adviser to the Kurdish regional government as Iraq wrote its Constitution  tough and sensitive talks not least because of issues like how Iraq would divide its vast oil wealth.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Walter Gibbs

articles.headline: At Fort Hood, Witness Credits Second Officer
articles.snippet: A witness disputed the Army’s initial version of how a shooting spree at Fort Hood, Tex., was brought to an end.
articles.abstract: A witness disputed the Army’s initial version of how a shooting spree at Fort Hood, Tex., was brought to an end.
articles.lead_paragraph: KILLEEN, Tex.  Sgt. Kimberly D. Munley has been applauded as a hero across the nation for shooting down Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan during the bloody rampage at Fort Hood last week. The account of heroism, given by the authorities, attracted the attention of newspapers, the networks and television talk shows.

articles.headline: In Charity Tax Filing, a Glimpse of Goldman
articles.snippet: Goldman Sachs has set aside $200 million to nearly double the size of its main foundation, which has placed a lot of its money in hedge funds and trades heavily in futures contracts.
articles.abstract: Goldman Sachs has set aside $200 million to nearly double the size of its main foundation, which has placed a lot of its money in hedge funds and trades heavily in futures contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: The latest tax filing for Goldman Sachs’s foundation is as thick as a phone book. The list of trades is more than 200 pages, single spaced. Goldman, it seems, invests like no other, even for its own charity.

articles.headline: A.M.D.-Intel Settlement Won’t End Their Woes
articles.snippet: Advanced Micro Devices, a rival maker of computer chips, had accused Intel of strong-arm tactics to pressure PC makers to buy Intel products.
articles.abstract: Advanced Micro Devices, a rival maker of computer chips, had accused Intel of strong-arm tactics to pressure PC makers to buy Intel products.
articles.lead_paragraph: The giant chip maker Intel, facing antitrust challenges around the world, announced on Thursday that it would pay $1.25 billion to settle its long-running disputes with its smaller rival, Advanced Micro Devices.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and James Kanter

articles.headline: Housing Agency’s Cash Reserves Down Sharply
articles.snippet: The government stopped short of saying the F.H.A. might need a direct bailout, but critics were less sure that help wasn’t needed.
articles.abstract: The government stopped short of saying the F.H.A. might need a direct bailout, but critics were less sure that help wasn’t needed.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Federal Housing Administration, the government agency whose loan-insurance programs have become a crucial source of support for the housing market, said on Thursday that its cash reserves had dwindled significantly in the last year as more borrowers defaulted on their mortgages.
